	<item>
		<title>Experiments in interactive video</title>
		<link>http://www.mztek.org/2009/03/experiments-in-interactive-video/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 02 Mar 2009 21:51:14 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Sophie</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.mztek.org/?p=153</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-155" title="isadora_nz_001_tn" src="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2009/03/isadora_nz_001_tn.jpg" alt="isadora_nz_001_tn" width="100" height="100" />

In this workshop we will make some funky visuals using live camera feed, pre-recorded video clips (feel free to bring your own... but make them small) and jpegs, (so bring some of those too). We will use sound and movement to trigger and manipulate visuals.

This workshop will involve some techy bits, like using a visual programming language, and it will also involve a bit of a boogie! Mary Clay is going to run a dance workshop for part of the session, and then we will combine the lot!

Don't feel you need to bring a laptop if that will stop you coming along, (although if you can do) you can still join in with all aspects, as we will have to take turns in using the projector anyway... unless you can bring one of those too.

This workshop will be an introduction to the software Isadora. This is really easy to use software for building patches, or programs, and
the basic idea behind it can be translated to other software such as PureData, Eyes web and MaxMSP.
<a href="http://www.sophiemcdonald.me.uk/art works/movies/mutants.AVI">Isadora example movie clip</a>
You can download the Isadora demo version here...<a href="http://www.troikatronix.com/izzy-download.html">http://www.troikatronix.com/izzy-download.html</a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>MzTEK July geekOut!</title>
		<link>http://www.mztek.org/?p=1466</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 07 Jul 2011 17:26:53 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Em</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.mztek.org/?p=1466</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2 style="text-align: left;"><a href="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/tn_soldering.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-1467 alignnone" src="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/tn_soldering-300x200.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="200" /></a><strong> </strong></h2>
<h2 style="text-align: left;"><strong>The geekOuts are back!</strong></h2>
<p style="text-align: left;">Bring your own work and ideas, or come and practice projects from our  previous workshops. We will have computers, a projector, previous  workshop pdf’s, and some tools and components available to borrow. If  you have something in mind to work on, please bring items you know you  will require just incase we don’t have them.</p>
<p style="text-align: left;">This will not be a tutored event, but an opportunity to play, learn  and practice anything that takes your fancy, and to catch up on the  SolarBots, Electronics for Absolute Beginners, Arduinorama and Shiver my  Teacup! workshops. It will also be an opportunity to show any projects,  either completed or in progress and get feedback.</p>
<p style="text-align: left;">If you have any kit from previous workshops, bring it along!</p>

<h2 style="text-align: left;">When &amp; Where</h2>
<p style="text-align: left;">Saturday 30th July 2011: 12pm – 5pm</p>
<p style="text-align: left;">Watermans Gallery, 40 High  Street Brentford, TW8 0DS</p>

<h2 style="text-align: left;">To Register</h2>
<p style="text-align: left;">£5
This is a women only session.
<a href="https://mztek.eventwax.com/mztek-july-geekout">SIGN UP HERE</a></p>
<p style="text-align: left;">If you have any queries, please contact emilie.giles@mztek.org</p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Chi-TEK Artist - Anna </title>
		<link>http://www.mztek.org/?p=1553</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Sophie</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.mztek.org/?p=1553</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[My name is Sophia and work for a festival called Internet Week Europe. Internet Week is a five-day festival of events to celebrate Europe's thriving internet industry and community. This year the festival runs from 7th-11th November.

Last year we had over 125 events which attracted over 10,000 attendees. Internet Week Europe 2011 is expected to draw more than 15,000 delegates to more than 200 events. Reflecting the Internet’s open structure, any organisation - from artists and investment banks to start-ups and meet-ups – can host an event during Internet Week Europe 2011. 

I came across your events and think that they are perfect for our audience and wanted to get in touch with you personally about hosting something during the week?
 
Below is a step-by-step of how to become an Official Event Partner. The login and
password allow you to edit your event at any time, just remember that every time
you change something the event will need to be re-approved.

1. Sign up as an event partner: https://www.internetweekeurope.com/partners/
login

2. Shortly after you will receive a confirmation email. Click on the link to activate
your account.

3. Log-in and register your event.

4. Wait for your event to be approved and then it will be live on the calendar.

Please feel free to get in contact and let me know how things are coming along and if
I can help in any way.

Many thanks,

Sophia]]></wp:comment_content>

	<item>
		<title>The Chi-TEK Tea Party, London Design Festival Digital Weekend</title>
		<link>http://www.mztek.org/?p=1730</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Sally</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.mztek.org/?p=1730</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The Chi-TEK Tea Party will not be your average garden tea party.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>1730</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2011-09-04 19:55:34</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>0000-00-00 00:00:00</wp:post_date_gmt>

	<item>
		<title>The Showcase</title>
		<link>http://www.mztek.org/programs/chi-tek/the-showcase/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 22 Sep 2011 17:54:38 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Sally</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.mztek.org/?page_id=1749</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2><span style="color: #000000;"><strong><a href="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/09/IMG_6009.jpg"><span style="color: #000000;"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-1783" title="" src="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/09/IMG_6009-224x300.jpg" alt="" width="224" height="300" /></span></a></strong></span><span style="color: #000000;"><strong>Mouna Andraos and Melissa Mongiat</strong></span></h2>
<em><span style="color: #000000;">On The Difficulty of Serving Tea</span></em><span style="color: #000000;"> (2011)</span>

<span style="color: #000000;">Traditional North African teapot and glasses, spoon, wood, pulleys and rope - Tea leaves, mint leaves, hot water, and sugar cubes to be added for the full experience.</span>

<span style="color: #000000;">—</span>

<span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: 16px; line-height: 20px; color: #000000;">This teapot set highlights the challenges behind the art of serving tea - and in particular traditional North African mint tea. An ancestral ritual is revisited. A set of pulleys, lots of string, a forgiving plate and a catapult invite participants into a strenuous, yet playful, challenge.</span>

<span style="color: #99cc00;"><a href="http://livingwithourtime.com"><span style="color: #99cc00;">http://livingwithourtime.com</span></a></span>

&nbsp;
<h2><span style="color: #000000;"><strong><a href="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/09/IMG_0571.jpg"><span style="color: #000000;"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-1796" title="" src="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/09/IMG_0571-300x225.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="225" /></span></a></strong></span></h2>
<h2><span class="Apple-style-span" style="line-height: 27px; color: #000000;"><strong>Sarah Angliss</strong></span></h2>
<span style="color: #000000;"><em>Relic</em> (2011)</span>

<span style="color: #000000;">Embossed aluminium teapot, Arduino, electronic components and cut glass</span>

<span style="color: #000000;">—</span>

<span style="color: #000000;">I’ve captured a fragment of the voice of Queen Elizabeth II in this relic from 1953: an aluminium teapot, polished to resemble silver and embossed to mimic the Imperial State Crown. You can manipulate this recording by picking up and moving the teapot. The 8-bit electronic voice and the teapot which contains it are both cheap, unconvincing simulacra. Each feels like a throwback to the past which itself is mimicking something all the more arcane. When I spotted the teapot in a Gloucester junk shop, I expected it to ring like a silver bell but found it had a disappointing, tinny sound as it’s made from pressed aluminium. Something about it reminded me of the upper class ‘cut glass’ accent, a sound I have always found rather tinny. The queen herself has been softening her accent and warming the timbre of her vowels over the sixty years (J. Harrington et al, 2000).</span>

<span style="color: #000000;">The voice is a downsampled, 4 second fragment of the Queen’s Christmas speech from 1957. I’ve stored this as an 8-bit, 6kHz sample on an Arduino board. The Arduino plays this at a varying rate, according to the movement or angle of the teapot which is measured using an accelerometer.  The playback method uses pulse-width modulation coupled with a low-pass filter, amplifier and speaker to convert the sample back into sound.</span>

<span style="color: #99cc00;"><a href="http://sarahangliss.com"><span style="color: #99cc00;">http://sarahangliss.com</span></a></span>
<h2><span style="color: #000000;"><strong><a href="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/09/6093988049_dd696581f4_b.jpg"><span style="color: #000000;"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-1784" title="" src="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/09/6093988049_dd696581f4_b-300x225.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="225" /></span></a>Rain Ashford</strong></span></h2>
<span style="color: #000000;"><em>Teapotty!</em> (2011)</span>

<span style="color: #000000;">Plastic teapot, electronic components, plastic cups, magnets, heart confetti</span>

<span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-size: 16px; line-height: 20px; color: #000000;"><strong>—</strong></span>

<span class="Apple-style-span" style="color: #444444; font-size: 16px; line-height: 20px;"><span style="color: #000000;"><strong>Teapotty! </strong>is a teapot sitting on a servo which takes readings from a magnetometer which is influenced by neodymium magnets in a cup. The magnetometer takes the reading from the north position, plays a bit of something similar to the Tetley Tea tune and then moves to a new position where the teacup moves to. BlinkM RGB LEDs indicate the new position of the teapot by changing colour based on the teapot’s new position from 0-180 degrees. I made some polymorph diffuser covers for them and also added heart confetti to emphasise the feeling of heart-warming happiness a cup of tea can bring :-</span>)</span>

<span style="color: #99cc00;"><a href="http://rainycatz.wordpress.com  "><span style="color: #99cc00;">http://rainycatz.wordpress.com</span></a></span>
<h2><span style="color: #000000;"><strong><span style="color: #99cc00;"><a href="http://rainycatz.wordpress.com  "><span style="color: #99cc00;"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-1785" title="" src="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/09/rr2-300x200.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="200" /></span></a></span>Katrin Baumgarten</strong></span></h2>
<span style="color: #000000;"><em>Raging Roger</em> (2011)</span>

<span style="color: #000000;">Porcelain teapot, copper, electronic components, water pump, ball bearing, servo motor, infrared sensor</span>

<strong>—</strong>
<div><span class="Apple-style-span" style="color: #000000; font-size: 16px; line-height: 20px;">What if an everyday object suddenly would strike back? <strong>Raging Roger</strong>, the spitting teapot, scans its environment turning 180 degrees back and forth, stops as soon as a person in close proximity is detected and spits at him.</span></div>
<span style="color: #000000;"><a href="http://katrinbaumgarten.de">http://katrinbaumgarten.de</a></span>
<h2><span style="color: #000000;"><strong><a href="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/09/LightPot-by-Tine-Bech-Photograph-by-Nicolai-Amter-3.jpg"><span style="color: #000000;"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-1786" title="" src="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/09/LightPot-by-Tine-Bech-Photograph-by-Nicolai-Amter-3-300x199.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="199" /></span></a>Tine Bech</strong></span></h2>
<span style="color: #000000;"><em>LightPot</em> (2011)</span>

<span style="color: #000000;">Glass teapot, wire, Arduino, GSM playground, LED lights</span>

<span class="Apple-style-span" style="color: #000000;"><strong><strong>—</strong></strong></span>

<span class="Apple-style-span" style="color: #000000;"><strong><strong></strong>LightPot </strong>is an interactive light teapot. It is like a small electronic creature, when you text the name of a colour to the <strong>LightPot </strong>it will change colour. The teapot is a classic glass teapot augmented with lots of white wire. Hidden inside the <strong>LightPot </strong>are electronics and LED lights. The light reflects in the white wire, changing the teapots appearance every time the audience sends a new text message, with a new colour.</span>

<span style="color: #000000;">The interface is simple, text ‘red’, ‘pink’, ‘cyan’ etc. to +44 (0)7530 450 348 and wait for the colour to change!</span>

<span style="color: #99cc00;"><a href="http://tinebech.com"><span style="color: #99cc00;">http://tinebech.com</span></a></span>
<h2><span style="color: #000000;"><strong><a href="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/09/teapot1.jpg"><span style="color: #000000;"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-1787" title="" src="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/09/teapot1-300x190.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="190" /></span></a>Clare Bowman</strong></span></h2>
<span style="color: #000000;"><em>Homing</em> (2011)</span>

<span style="color: #000000;">Missile switch cover, switch, Arduino, battery, piezo, LED, diffuser</span>

<span class="Apple-style-span" style="color: #000000;"><strong><strong>—</strong></strong></span>

<span class="Apple-style-span" style="color: #000000;"><strong><strong></strong></strong>The apocalyptic teapot is a planned heirloom, created to preserve the great tradition of tea drinking. In case of civilisation breakdown, the teapot will act as a homing device. The user is led to a capsule buried underground containing tea, utensils and an envelope of objects encapsulating home for four generations of O’Shea women.</span>

<span style="color: #000000;">Tea drinking items: an origami kettle, cup and stirrer, teabag, sugar cube and powdered milk.</span>

<span style="color: #000000;">O’Shea items: a recipe, lavender, playing card and an ultrasound, represent food, rest, play and family from Nana, Mum, Clare and future daughter Nixie</span>

<span style="color: #000000;">Originally, the apocalyptic teapot used three LDRs taped to the screen of an Android device. For increased reliability, the V&amp;A demonstration prototype now has a three axis tilt-compensating LSM303DLH Magnetometer. The next revision will incorporate a Venus GPS breakout and patch aerial.</span>

<span style="color: #000000;">Together the apocalyptic teapot and tea capsule provide reassurance to tea lovers that the civilised world’s favourite beverage will always be preserved.</span>

<span style="color: #99cc00;"><a href="http://tacticalendar.co.uk"><span style="color: #99cc00;">http://tacticalendar.co.uk</span></a></span>
<h2><span style="color: #000000;"><strong><a href="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/09/stormy-teapot1-cheang.jpg"><span style="color: #000000;"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-1788" title="" src="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/09/stormy-teapot1-cheang-300x225.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="225" /></span></a>Shu Lea Cheang</strong></span></h2>
<span style="color: #000000;"><em>Stormy Weather Stirred</em> (2011)</span>

<span style="color: #000000;">Yellow teapot, NanoSmano Sajica circuit board, speaker and five tea bags</span>

<span class="Apple-style-span" style="color: #000000;"><strong><strong>—</strong></strong></span>

<span class="Apple-style-span" style="color: #000000;"><strong><strong></strong></strong>I found this yellow Tetley teapot laying quietly among vintage silver Morrocan teapots in the cupboard at the home of madame Rokia Ben Brahim, a 93 year old Algerian woman working all her life as a cleaning lady in Paris.</span>

<span style="color: #000000;">In a workshop conducted by Marc Dusseiller at la Fonderie de l’Image, I soldered Vive la Resistance aka NanoSmano Sajica, a mini circuit with an oscillator and a resistive gas sensor. I installed the NanoSmano Sajica inside the teacup, leaving its circuit board hanging out along with other tea bag labels. It produces sound responding to touch and breath.</span>

<span style="color: #000000;">Tetley was the first company to launch tea in tea bags in the United Kingdom in 1953. Tea leaves packed into instant tea bags, no fortune to be told. Storm in the teacup, storm out of the teacup. A cup of tea for stormy weather.</span>

<span style="color: #000000;">Stormy Weather, a song written by Harold Arlen and Ted Koehler, first recorded by Ethel Waters in 1933, later recorded &amp; reinterpreted by a string of fine musicians.</span>

<span style="color: #000000;">Touch the circuit board. Blind read the fortune. The noise storms out of the teapot, amplified anarchy. The blue tune of Stormy Weather meets the teapot upheaval, stormy weather stirred and disturbed.</span>

<span style="color: #99cc00;"><a href="http://mauvaiscontact.info/"><span style="color: #99cc00;">http://mauvaiscontact.info/</span></a></span>
<h2><span style="color: #000000;"><strong><a href="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/09/IMG_0074.jpg"><span style="color: #000000;"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-1789" title="" src="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/09/IMG_0074-300x224.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="224" /></span></a>Alexandra Deschamps-Sonsino and </strong><strong>Campbell Orme</strong></span></h2>
<span style="color: #000000;"><em>Utah</em> (2011)</span>

<span style="color: #000000;">Nylon, acrylic paint and varnish</span>

<strong><strong>—</strong></strong>
<div><span class="Apple-style-span" style="color: #000000; font-size: 16px; line-height: 20px;"><strong>Utah </strong>is a response to the Utah teapot, a standard reference object in the computer graphics community. The complexity of the object lies in the different types of curves that make it up, and therefore make it one of the most difficult objects to learn how to build in 3D. The original teapot given by MzTEK was rendered as accurately as possible and divided into pieces which were then prototyped using SLS technology (selective laser sintering). The pieces were then painted to make them look as close to porcelain as possible, but in areas which aren’t usually glazed, and ignoring some key areas that should. The ubiquity of this everyday object is forgotten and the object, its process and materials, made to be reconsidered in light of new technologies.</span></div>
<span style="color: #99cc00;"><a href="http://designswarm.com"><span style="color: #99cc00;">http://designswarm.com</span></a></span>
<h2><span style="color: #000000;"><strong><a href="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/09/TeaCosy1.jpg"><span style="color: #000000;"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-1790" title="" src="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/09/TeaCosy1-300x199.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="199" /></span></a>Anna Dumitriu</strong></span></h2>
<span style="color: #000000;"><em>Biohacked Tea Cosy</em> (2011)</span>

<span style="color: #000000;">Bacteria, calico, embroidery silk, natural antibiotics, video player, film of bacteria under the microscope</span>

<span class="Apple-style-span" style="color: #000000;"><strong><strong>—</strong></strong></span>

<span class="Apple-style-span" style="color: #000000;"><strong><strong></strong></strong>The <strong>Biohacked Tea Cosy </strong>employed ‘kitchen science’ or DIYbio techniques to embed the cloth with pigments from normal flora bacteria from forgotten remains of milky tea left overnight. The embroidery is made using silk stained with natural antibiotics, including green tea and cloves. The process employed in its production could potentially be used to selectively breed green tea ‘resistant’ organisms and investigates our complex and precarious relationship with the microbial world, which we still know relatively little about.</span>

<span style="color: #99cc00;"><a href="http://unnecessaryresearch.org"><span style="color: #99cc00;">http://unnecessaryresearch.org</span></a></span>

<span style="color: #99cc00;"><a href="http://normalflora.co.uk"><span style="color: #99cc00;">http://normalflora.co.uk</span></a></span>
<h2><span style="color: #000000;"><strong><span style="color: #99cc00;"><a href="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/09/P1010604-Tea-Flock-julie-freeman.jpg"><span style="color: #99cc00;"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-1795" title="" src="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/09/P1010604-Tea-Flock-julie-freeman-300x225.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="225" /></span></a></span>Julie Freeman</strong></span></h2>
<span style="color: #000000;"><em>Tea Flock</em> (2011)</span>

<span style="color: #000000;">Ceramic teapots, syrian dwarf hamster, electronic components</span>

<span class="Apple-style-span" style="color: #000000;"><strong><strong>—</strong></strong></span>

<span class="Apple-style-span" style="color: #000000;"><strong><strong></strong></strong>A dynamic gaggle of unfilled vessels flock to tea-rich lands for a nourishing brew.</span>

<span style="color: #000000;">Social tea rituals fulfill global migration and are hacked into local cultures. Gathering for coffee, shoaling for cake, flocking for tea...</span>

<span style="color: #000000;"><strong>Tea Flock </strong>infuses migrating rituals and represents emerging patterns through the group behaviour of objects, using data from migratory birds to-and-from tea-growing</span>

<a href="http://translatingnature.org">http://translatingnature.org</a>
<h2><span style="color: #000000;"><strong><a href="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/09/SoundMap.jpg"><span style="color: #000000;"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-1791" title="" src="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/09/SoundMap-300x236.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="236" /></span></a></strong></span></h2>
<h2><span style="color: #000000;"><strong>G.Hack</strong></span></h2>
<span style="color: #000000;"><em>Sound Mapping London Tea Houses</em> (2011)</span>

<span style="color: #000000;">Hardware: glass teapot, IR LED’s, electronic components, wooden box with dual layer perspex top, projector, laptop, speakers, IR camera</span>

<span style="color: #000000;">Software: reacTIVision, Max/MSP, Processing</span>

<strong><strong>—</strong></strong>
<div><span class="Apple-style-span" style="color: #000000; font-size: 16px; line-height: 20px;">Navigate London through its contemporary tea culture. Place the teapot on a borough of your choice to hear the sounds of tea houses from that locale. Inspired by London’s vibrant tea drinking culture, this interactive sonic map explores different places and spaces where tea drinking is taking place. Through listening in, the spatial and social aspects of tea houses are unveiled. <strong>Sound Mapping London Tea Houses </strong>invites visitors to share the sounds and stories of their own favourite tea house in London.</span></div>
<span style="color: #000000;">The work is developed using reacTIVision, an open source, cross-platform computer vision framework for tangible user interfaces, Max/MSP and Processing. Sounds were recorded on different devices by G.Hackers: Nela Brown, Ilze Black, Alice Clifford, Nicola Plant, Kavin Preethi Narasimhan, Sam Duffy and Sara Heitlinger. G.Hack is an art and technology lab for women at Queen Mary University of London.</span>

<span style="color: #99cc00;"><a href="http://ghack.eecs.qmul.ac.uk/"><span style="color: #99cc00;">http://ghack.eecs.qmul.ac.uk</span></a></span>
<h2><span style="color: #000000;"><strong><a href="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/09/Picture-1.png"><span style="color: #000000;"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-1792" title="" src="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/09/Picture-1-300x214.png" alt="" width="300" height="214" /></span></a>Syuzi Pakhchyan</strong></span></h2>
<span style="color: #000000;"><em>PC = TB + 2BT + 6WT</em> (2011)</span>

<span style="color: #000000;">Electroluminescent film, electronic components, mirrored-plexiglass</span>

<span class="Apple-style-span" style="color: #000000;"><strong><strong><strong>—</strong></strong></strong></span>

<span class="Apple-style-span" style="color: #000000;"><strong><strong><strong></strong></strong>PC = TB + 2BT + 6WT </strong>is an abridged scientific formula for a perfect cup of tea. This project reflects on the concept of perfectibility, specifically the use of science and technology to seek the chimera of perfection. Today algorithms are used to identify a perfect “love” match, scientifically tested formulas are discovered for the perfect cup of tea and, in the near future, science and technology will help us attain human perfection through the genetic design of our offspring.</span>

<span style="color: #000000;">As human experiences are obviously subjective, can science and technology really be used to harness human nature?</span>

<span style="color: #000000;">The form of the teapot itself was inspired by origami: its structured, formulaic and repeatable design. The teapot cycles through three different patterns of light reflecting the brew time, wait time and pour time.</span>

<span style="color: #99cc00;"><a href="http://fashioningtech.com"><span style="color: #99cc00;">http://fashioningtech.com</span></a></span>
<h2><span style="color: #000000;"><strong><a href="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/09/01082011947.jpg"><span style="color: #000000;"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-1797" title="" src="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/09/01082011947-300x225.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="225" /></span></a>Artemis Papageorgiou</strong></span></h2>
<span style="color: #000000;"><em>This Is Not A Teapot</em> (2011)</span>

<span style="color: #000000;">Polyester teapots with Sound Playback Module</span>

<strong><strong>—</strong></strong>

<strong><strong></strong></strong><span class="Apple-style-span" style="color: #000000;"><strong>This Is Not A Teapot </strong>is inspired by the semiotics of language used in the homonym painting of Magritte (Ceci n’est pas une pipe). What happens to an object when its formal language does not speak of the object anymore? What is a teapot enhanced with different functions and materiality?</span>

<span style="color: #000000;">The project attempts to break down objectivity into isolated parts, the form and function, and collage them into a new object reminiscent of a teapot. By replicating an ordinary teapot out of different materials and electronics a hybrid object i</span><span style="color: #000000;">s now conceived, definitely not a teapot.</span>

<span style="color: #99cc00;"><a href="http://artemispapageorgiou.com"><span style="color: #99cc00;">http://artemispapageorgiou.com</span></a></span>

<span style="color: #99cc00;"><a href="http://athensplaython.org"><span style="color: #99cc00;">http://athensplaython.org</span></a></span>
<h2><span style="color: #000000;"><strong><a href="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/09/6031305645_b503c2253e_o.jpg"><span style="color: #000000;"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-1798" title="" src="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/09/6031305645_b503c2253e_o-300x225.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="225" /></span></a>Mika Satomi </strong></span></h2>
<span style="color: #000000;"><em>Suicidal Teapot</em> (2011)</span>

<span style="color: #000000;">Fabric, thread spool, wire, thermoplastic, conductive thread, LilyPad Arduino, electronic components</span>

<span class="Apple-style-span" style="color: #000000;"><strong><strong><strong>—</strong></strong></strong></span>

<span class="Apple-style-span" style="color: #000000;"><strong><strong><strong></strong></strong>Suicidal Teapot </strong>is a teapot, which hits itself until it breaks. We may sympathize with its action as an attempt of suicide, or may observe its motion as a pure mechanical function. In any case, the self-destruction continues until the teapot shatters into pieces, splashing out the tea it contains.</span>

<span style="color: #000000;">The destruction will be completed with high-voltage short-circuit blast on the fabric circuit beneath. You may use this teapot as a suicidal apparatus, by sitting beside with a cup of tea and waiting until the final moment arrives. If you are lucky, you will be “properly” electrocuted.</span>

<span style="color: #000000;">Acknowledgement: I would like to thank Gabriel Wegscheider and Ingo Randolf for their support and advice during the first prototyping phase. I believe technology is there for both man and woman.</span>

<span style="color: #99cc00;"><a href="http://nerding.at"><span style="color: #99cc00;">http://nerding.at</span></a></span>

<span style="color: #99cc00;"><a href="http://kobakant.at"><span style="color: #99cc00;">http://kobakant.at</span></a></span>
<h2><span style="color: #000000;"><strong><a href="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/09/1.jpg"><span style="color: #000000;"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-1799" title="" src="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/09/1-300x179.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="179" /></span></a>Eunjoo Shin</strong></span></h2>
<span style="color: #000000;"><em>Bow &amp; Tea</em> (2011)</span>

<span style="color: #000000;">Aluminium, acrylic panel, resin, custom-made hardware</span>

<span class="Apple-style-span" style="color: #000000;"><strong><strong><strong>—</strong></strong></strong></span>

<span class="Apple-style-span" style="color: #000000;"><strong><strong><strong></strong></strong>Bow &amp; Tea </strong>is a designed device, which suggests humorous tea-making and serving for others by controlling the speed of dropping tea leaves. With this given process, we can share enjoyable tea break and bow for thankful serving.</span>

<span style="color: #99cc00;"><a href="http://ejoo.org"><span style="color: #99cc00;">http://ejoo.org</span></a></span>

<span style="color: #99cc00;"><a href="http://comms.me"><span style="color: #99cc00;">http://comms.me</span></a></span>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Press Release</title>
		<link>http://www.mztek.org/programs/chi-tek/press-release/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 19 Sep 2011 11:29:32 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Sally</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.mztek.org/?page_id=1763</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Calling All Girl Geeks!  Techy Tea Pots at the Chi-TEK Tea Party
V&amp;A Sackler Centre for Arts Education
London Design Festival 2011 / V&amp;A Digital Design Weekend  Saturday 24 &amp; Sunday 25 September 2011

Chi-TEK, a tea inspired showcase celebrating the work of internationally acclaimed women artists who utilise computers, electronics and technology in their work, will be launched at the V&amp;A Sackler Centre for Arts Education as part of the London Design Festival during V&amp;A Digital Design Weekend, Saturday 24 &amp; Sunday 25 September 2011.

20 women artists and designers have been invited to hack a teapot to showcase their unique use of technology in the arts.  This is the first time so many contemporary women artists working with technology have been brought together under one roof.  Chi-TEK, based on the acronym for Computer Human Interaction - aims to raise the profile of women artists, an under-represented group in this pioneering field.  World-renowned artists Shu Lea Cheang and Tine Bech are among the participants, who include; interaction designers, sound artists, industrial designers, bio artists, architects, and performance artists, as well as women who work with wearable technologies and sustainability. The Chi-TEK showcase will be available to view at V&amp;A Sackler Centre for Arts Education from September (10:00 -17:45).

A two day Chi-TEK Tea Party will be held during the V&amp;A Digital Design Weekend, Saturday 24 &amp; Sunday 25 September 2011. Contributing artists will present their teapots and talk about their specialist techniques during a series of scheduled presentations over tea and cake. Drop-in tinkering demos will run throughout the weekend and the teapots will then be showcased until the end of November. The Chi-TEK showcase and V&amp;A Digital Design Weekend are part of London Design Festival, 17—25 September 2011 and also coincides with the Crafts Council’s Power of Making exhibition, also at the V&amp;A.

Chi-TEK has been organised by MzTEK, the not-for-profit women’s arts collective that provides women artists with technical skills in the fields of new media and computer arts.  Based in London and supported by Hackney arts institution SPACE, they host a range of workshops, talks and self-initiated tinker sessions across London with plans to spread across the UK in 2012.  As part of Chi-TEK, MzTEK will also host a series of crockery-themed workshops including Shiver me Tea Cups workshops where women can learn how to make their favourite tea cups wobble and shiver when their tea is getting cold.

For press information, images and interviews with participating artists please contact:

MzTEK
Jane McGrath at jane.mcgrath@mztek.org or 07960994753
Siobhan Groark at siobhan.groark@mztek.org or 07835496255

http://mztek.org

Visitor information is available from the V&amp;A website www.vam.ac.uk

Editors Notes:
Supported by the National Lottery for Arts Council England]]></content:encoded>

		<title>MzTEK Unplugged : Ruth Catlow</title>
		<link>http://www.mztek.org/2009/03/ruth-catlow/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 27 Mar 2009 13:03:21 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Sophie</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.mztek.org/?p=143</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Hey folks,

Don't miss our next MzTEK Unplugged session on April 1, presenting Ruth Catlow from Furtherfield.org and HTTP Gallery.

When:  Wednesday, April 1, 7 - 9pm

Where: Leon Bankside, , 7 Canvey Street, SE1 0HS (behind the Tate Modern)

Ruth will talk about Furtherfield.org, an independent media arts
organisation that provides contexts and platforms for creating, viewing,
discussing and learning about experimental practices at the intersection
of art, technology and social change.
<a href="http://www.furtherfield.org">www.furtherfield.org</a>
<a href="http://www.http.uk.net">www.http.uk.net</a>

Ruth is a media artist, educator and co-founder and co-director of
Furtherfield.org and HTTP Gallery in North London. She works
collaboratively with other artists, technologists, musicians, writers,
activists and thinkers from around the world, to devise and realise
artistic projects that explore relationship, connectedness and
participation; developing platforms with their own distinct artistic and
social contexts. Her work has been exhibited internationally and in the
UK at venues including the CCA, Glasgow and The Baltic, Gateshead.
<a href="http://www.furtherfield.org">www.furtherfield.org</a>

Open to the public. Free.

Can't make it?  Check out our exciting <a href="http://www.mztek.org/pub-meet/" target="_blank">Unplugged calendar</a>!  We have a fantastic line-up of artists, scholars, and organizers presenting through June 2009.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>MzTEK Unplugged : Ele Carpenter **this Wed 17th June**</title>
		<link>http://www.mztek.org/2009/06/mztek-unplugged-ele-carpenter/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 14 Jun 2009 16:19:25 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Sophie</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.mztek.org/?p=146</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Ele will be talking about her current research project <a href="http://www.elecarpenter.org.uk/">Open Source Embroidery.</a> Please feel free to bring along your knitting and coding patterns  to share and modify.

This Wednesday 17th June from 7-9pm
Location:
Leon restaurant, Bankside, 7 Canvey Street (Behind the Tate Modern) London, SE1 9AN<a href="http://maps.google.com/maps/ms?hl=en&amp;geocode=&amp;ie=UTF8&amp;om=1&amp;msa=0&amp;msid=106000309244585811318.0004627a5e16ecbff9a01&amp;ll=51.506205,-0.098598&amp;spn=0.004902,0.012059&amp;z=17" target="_blank"> See MAP</a>

<img class="alignleft" src="http://www.open-source-embroidery.org.uk/osepics/Patchworkviewer.jpg" alt="" width="283" height="348" />

The Open Source Embroidery project was initiated by Ele Carpenter in 2005. The project has grown to support and facilitate a range of artists practice investigating the relationship between programming for embroidery and computing. It's based on the common characteristics of needlework crafts and open source computer programming: gendered obsessive attention to detail; shared social process of development; and a transparency of process and product. Open Source Embroidery is a socially engaged art project developed through workshops and an email list: os-embroidery@googlegroups.com There are also groups on Facebook and Flickr.

Ele's blog <a href="http://www.eleweekend.blogspot.com/">Ele Weekend</a> documents the project and posts information about current workshops and exhibitions.

Ele Carpenter is an independent curator and researcher based in Umea in Northeast Sweden, Newcastle upon Tyne and London, UK. She is currently undertaking a Research Fellowship at HUMlab in affiliation with the BildMuseet at the University of Umea, Sweden. Her curatorial practice responds to specific socio-political cultural contexts in collaboration with individuals, groups and organisations. Her life-long interest in the relationship between creativity and political action, has been influenced by her formative years at <a href="http://www.elecarpenter.org.uk/">Greenham Common Women's Peace Camp</a> and on Cruisewatch. Fleeing the polarities of activism to join the art-world, she has continuously interrogated the relationship between cultural and political change through curatorial creative practice. Her research has written, curatorial and creative outcomes including mapping, embroidery, and research projects on this website.

Ele recieved her PhD on the relationship between politicised socially engaged art and new media art, with CRUMB at the University of Sunderland in 2008. She has a Post Graduate Diploma in Art Gallery &amp; Museum Studies from the University of Manchester (1996), and undertook her BA (Hons) in Fine Art at Leeds Metropolitan University (1993).]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>MzTEK Unplugged : Julie Freeman</title>
		<link>http://www.mztek.org/2009/03/mztek-unplugged-julie-freeman/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 03 Mar 2009 12:04:52 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Sophie</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.mztek.org/?p=160</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="color: #000000;">.</span>

<span style="color: #000000;">.</span>

<img class="alignleft" title="Catching Tagged Fish" src="http://www.juliefreeman.co.uk/lake/img/photos/02_catching.jpg" alt="" width="138" height="138" /> Julie will be introducing the politics of Open Source software and code, and will introduce some of the useful programs, packages and tools available for artists, and tools she uses in her work.

Julie Freeman’s work explores transforming complex processes into sound compositions, objects and visualisations. Her work spans visual, audio and digital art forms and explores the relationship between science, nature and how humans interact with it. For the past 12 years her work has focused on using electronic technologies to “translate nature” – whether through the sound of torrential rain falling on a giant rhubarb leaf, a pair of mobile concrete speakers lurking in galleries haranguing passers by or by providing an interactive platform from which to view the flap, twitch and prick of dogs’ ears.  Her pioneering artwork The Lake used hydrophones, custom software and advanced technology to track electronically tagged fish and translate their movement into an audio-visual experience. Julie holds an MA in Digital Art from the Lansdown Centre for Electronic Arts, Middlesex University, and is a NESTA fellow and Wellcome Trust arts awardee. Her work has been exhibited across the UK, including at the Institute of Contemporary Arts and the Science Museum, and internationally in Brazil, Croatia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Russia, and the USA.

<a href="http://www.translatingnature.org">www.translatingnature.org</a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How to get the best out of your BitTorrent:</title>
		<link>http://www.mztek.org/2009/03/how-to-get-the-best-out-of-your-bittorrent/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 03 Mar 2009 11:49:09 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Sophie</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.mztek.org/?p=163</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<span class="status_body">We'll be meeting</span> in Shoreditch / Old Street area (E1).  If you'll take part in the workshop, please <a href="mailto:info@mztek.org">email us </a>for the specific address and details in advance.
We will provide the pizza!!

<span style="color: #000000;">.</span>

Caroline will introduce:

BitTorrent
Choosing the best service
Safety - avoiding viruses and the law

Common downloaded File types &amp; how to play them
DIVX
ISO
RAR, TAR
Others

Premium newsgroups

Ripping streams

Ripping DVDs

mounting ISOs / virtual dives

And if there is anything else you know you don't know about this kind of thing, she is happy to take requests and suggestions for the workshop content. Email them to info(at)mztek.org]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>MzTEK Unplugged: Lisa Haskel</title>
		<link>http://www.mztek.org/2009/03/mztek-unplugged-lisa-haskel/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 14 Mar 2009 09:24:37 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Sophie</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.mztek.org/?p=209</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="color: #000000;">.</span>

<span style="color: #000000;">.
</span>

<span style="color: #000000;">.</span>
<img class="size-full wp-image-210 alignleft" title="Lisa Haskel" src="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2009/03/1.jpg" alt="Lisa Haskel" width="166" height="166" />

Programming instructor Lisa Haskel will explore samples of student projects she has supported to open up discussion on the importance (or otherwise) of programming knowledge for media artists, and strategies for developing these skills.

Lisa has worked with media artists for over 20 years, originally as an organiser/administrator, and more recently supplying technical support and teaching the technical fundamentals of creative work on the Web including networking, programming and server administration.

7 - 9pm at the <a href="www.fancyapint.com/pubs/pub3822.html" target="_blank">Britannia Pub</a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>MzTEK Unplugged: Alex McLean ***TONIGHT***</title>
		<link>http://www.mztek.org/2009/05/mztek-unplugged-alex-mclean/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 08 May 2009 17:12:52 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Sophie</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.mztek.org/?p=231</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="color: #000000;">.
.
.</span>
<img class="alignleft" src="http://yaxu.org/knitting.jpg" alt="" width="200" height="250">  Alex will be talking about the nature of code, of geometrical space, and the relationship between them.  This will lead into a demo of vocable synthesis, a way of controlling synthesised drums with words.

Alex is one third of the live coding band <a href="http://slub.org/" target="_blank">http://slub.org</a>, a PhD student at Goldsmiths digital studios and co-organiser of various events including dorkbotlondon.  He enjoys computer programming as a way of making music and of interacting with the world.  More info about his projects and activities may be found at <a href="http://yaxu.org/" target="_blank">http://yaxu.org/</a>
<br />
<h3>Location: </h3> Leon restaurant, Bankside,  7 Canvey Street (Behind the Tate Modern) London SE1 9AN <a href="http://maps.google.com/maps/ms?hl=en&geocode=&ie=UTF8&om=1&msa=0&msid=106000309244585811318.0004627a5e16ecbff9a01&ll=51.506205,-0.098598&spn=0.004902,0.012059&z=17">map</a> <br /> <br />]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>MzTEK Unplugged: Alex Zivanovic</title>
		<link>http://www.mztek.org/2009/04/mztek-unplugged-alex-zivanovic/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 12 Apr 2009 17:23:22 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Sophie</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.mztek.org/?p=233</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div class="mceTemp"></div>
<div class="mceTemp"></div>
<img class="size-full wp-image-325" title="alex" src="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2009/03/portrait-lrg-112x150.jpg" alt="Alex Zivanovic" width="112" height="150" />

Alex  will talk about the creative uses of Physical Computing - sensing and controlling the real world using programmable microcontrollers. In particular, he will talk about the Arduino (<a href="http://www.arduino.cc">www.arduino.cc</a>), a low cost microcontroller system specifically aimed at artists and designers. He'll show how the system can be used to make interactive devices and installations.

Alex is a freelance technology consultant, educator and artist, specialising in the field of Physical Computing (sensing and controlling the physical world with computers).  He is a visiting tutor at the Royal College of Art and Goldsmiths and a visiting scholar at the Lansdown Centre for Electronic Arts at Middlesex. Previously, he was a researcher at Imperial College London, developing mechatronic systems for medical use, including medical robotics and virtual reality training systems for surgery.

<a href="http://www.zivanovic.co.uk">www.zivanovic.co.uk</a>

Wednesday, April 15, 7—9pm

At: Leon Bankside (behind Tate Modern—map below!)
<small><a style="color:#0000FF;text-align:left" href="http://maps.google.com/maps?f=q&amp;source=embed&amp;hl=en&amp;geocode=&amp;q=7+Canvey+Street,+Southwark,+London+SE1,+United+Kingdom&amp;sll=51.510826,-0.097032&amp;sspn=0.011138,0.027637&amp;ie=UTF8&amp;ll=51.513657,-0.094757&amp;spn=0.016024,0.025749&amp;z=14&amp;iwloc=A">View Larger Map</a></small>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>The WishList!</title>
		<link>http://www.mztek.org/2009/03/the-wishlist/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 15 Mar 2009 21:33:45 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Sally</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.mztek.org/?p=272</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Welcome to the Wish List.  We're opening up a comment-style forum where you can add and bounce ideas, thoughts, and suggestions for course material.

With the help of SPACE studios and our co-organizers, we are actively recruiting tutors for specialty workshops ranging the new media gamut. Please <a href="mailto:info@mztek.org">email us</a> if you are interested in teaching workshops.

Why not chime in and put in your two cents?  We'll try to match a tutor to your course wish, although suggestions/recommendations are always a help.

<strong>Suggested / Requested courses:</strong>

<strong>* Toy Hacking/Physical Computing</strong>

<strong>* CCTV Hacking</strong>

<strong>* Processing</strong>

<strong>* RFID Tags</strong>
<strong>* Using sensors: Arduinos, stamps</strong>

<strong>* Pervasive media / Ubiquitous Computing</strong>

<strong>*Arduinos</strong>

<strong>*Pure Data / Max
</strong>

<strong>*Gaming Tools
</strong>

<strong>*3D Game Design</strong>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>P2P tinkers with Isadora</title>
		<link>http://www.mztek.org/2009/03/here-we-go/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 26 Mar 2009 14:08:21 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Sally</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.mztek.org/?p=279</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Over the last month, we've kicked off a couple of awesome projects: MzTEK <a href="http://www.mztek.org/?page_id=7">Unplugged</a> pub meets and <a href="http://www.mztek.org/?page_id=5">P2P workshops</a>.  The aim?  To foster discussion and skills exchange in new media art, and explore somewhat idiosyncratic (yet  quality) alternative learning environments.  Students teach students, guest speakers present over candlelight and drinks at the local  — a bit different from your average uni course.

At our last P2P, meeting up in Bermondsey, Sophie walked us through <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isadora_(software)">Isadora</a>— software that provides an interactive element to audio and visual input/output.  Isadora is a graphical programming environment that lets you easily link together effects, input, output, and other pre-made patches to create powerful interactive audiovisuals.

[caption id="attachment_281" align="alignnone" width="300" caption="Here&#39;s some visuals of our own, tapping the first known woman programmer (long before computers),  with Isadora."]<a href="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2009/03/picture-1.png"><img class="size-medium wp-image-281" title="picture-1" src="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2009/03/picture-1-300x178.png" alt="picture-1" width="300" height="178" /></a>[/caption]

The effects we played with were pretty simple, but we got the idea that this stuff can do some very, very cool things if you tinker with it long enough.  Maybe this is how I can learn to VJ?  The only downside is that Isadora will set you back about £200 (if you want to save your files).  Here's an example of a cool video effect (sort of like difference) applied to a clip I took at the <a href="www.kinetica-artfair.com/">Kinetica</a> fair :  <a href="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2009/03/testing-isadora-movie.mov">testing-isadora-movie</a>.

But before we delved into Isadora, Mary — a choreographer from Devon — walked us (or should I say chasséed?) through a breezy series of physical movements and routines with the idea we could then apply these towards a project in Isadora. (Isadora, I should mentioned, is named after the famed American dancer Isadora Duncan, and its original raison d'etre was to provide dancers and choreographers with new means for interactive movement capture.)]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Unplugged: Hey Ada!</title>
		<link>http://www.mztek.org/2009/03/ada-lovelace-unplugged/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 23 Mar 2009 23:44:40 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Sally</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.mztek.org/?p=308</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Last week, programmer, arts organizer,  and mom Lisa Haskel helped us kick off our fortnightly <a href="http://www.mztek.org/pub-meet/">Unplugged</a> series at The Britannia.  With a small friendly mix including curators, academics, artists, and writers, we gathered around a cozy candlelit corner to talk programming in the arts as well as international communication between artists in the early days of email.  Having grown up on email, myspace, and YouTube (well, practically), it's difficult to imagine a time before artists could display &amp; discuss their work easily on public forums such as web sites and video hosting sites.

Lisa's career has focused over the years on the intersection of arts practice and computing, and for that reason, we're honoring her here as part of <a href="http://www.pledgebank.com/AdaLovelaceDay" target="_blank">our pledge to Ada Lovelace Day</a>.  <span style="font-family: Arial,Helvetica;">An organiser, adminstrator and commentator in the  field of media art and new media practice, Lisa has worked for the Arts Council of England,</span> created drupal sites for folks like National Strategies, studied interactive development at the Rick Center for persons with disabilities, and taught PHP and CMS to arts students at Ravensbourne College (to name a few).

At Unplugged, Lisa walked us through a few of her favorite former students' projects—some fantastic explorations of more traditional media artists employing Web development tools in unpredictable ways:

[caption id="attachment_290" align="alignleft" width="291" caption="Jee Hyun-oh&#39;s delicate, illuminated garden of a social network."]<a href="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2009/03/gori.jpg"><img class="size-full wp-image-290" title="gori" src="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2009/03/gori.jpg" alt="Delicate, illuminated garden of our social network" width="291" height="218" /></a>[/caption]

Jee Hyun-oh's <span class="title2"><a href="http://www.gorigardeners.net/" target="_blank">GORI.Node Garden</a>:  an installation piece of mechanical flowers that vibrate when stimulated by network activity.</span>

[caption id="attachment_291" align="alignleft" width="300" caption="Shanyin Hung&#39;s  Farmer Brown&#39;s Journal"]<a href="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2009/03/farmerjournal.jpg"><img class="size-medium wp-image-291" title="farmerjournal" src="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2009/03/farmerjournal-300x292.jpg" alt="This is a caption" width="300" height="292" /></a>[/caption]

Shanyin Hung's  <a href="http://www.limboofnodes.com/project/farmer-browns-journal" target="_blank">Farmer Brown's Journal</a> promotes the idea of knowing where your food is sourced from as a CMS-driven web site.

Dave Miller's <a href="http://davemiller.org/index.php?nav_item=Gallery&amp;gallery_nav=cartoon_generator" target="_blank">online comic strip generator</a> invites internauts to be authors, collaborators, and characters in an online comic story, mashed up with dialogue generated by live news taken from web feeds.

<a href="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2009/03/comic.jpg"><img class="size-full wp-image-294 alignleft" title="comic" src="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2009/03/comic.jpg" alt="comic" width="495" height="193" /></a>

Our forthcoming workshops and our Unplugged calendar are posted online for all you MzTEK internauts to check out and participate.

If you're not in the know yet, <a href="http://www.mztek.org/peer-meet/">tonight</a> we're learning to Bit Torrent to the max, and next week <a href="http://www.mztek.org/ruth-catlow/">Ruth Catlow from Http Gallery / Furtherfield</a> will present at Unplugged.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:post_name>ada-lovelace-unplugged</wp:post_name>

	<item>
		<title>A [ space ] to hack</title>
		<link>http://www.mztek.org/2009/04/a-space-to-hack/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 24 Apr 2009 17:55:27 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Sally</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.mztek.org/?p=332</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Last week, huddled round the large bench at Leon Bankside, technology consultant <a href="http://www.senster.com/alex_zivanovic/index.htm">Alex Zivanovic</a> took us through a short journey of his impressive career in electronics, mechanics, a combo of the two (mechatronics) and his current work now in physical computing and design.  In particular, Alex lingered over a project that particularly fascinates him:  <a href="http://www.senster.com/">the Senster</a>.  An enormous hydraulic robot created in the early '70s, it sounds misleadingly menacing.  The giant, kinetic sculpture resembled a curious giraffe (or herbivore dinosaur.)  <img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-340" title="senster12-lrg" src="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2009/04/senster12-lrg-300x216.jpg" alt="senster12-lrg" width="221" height="159" />

Towering above its visitors, the sculpture was ahead of its time:  a combination of microphones, sensors, and a computer-implemented behavioral system gave life to the Senster, whose head would follow those around it, attracted to their sounds. Forty years later—eons in dork years—we're still tinkering with sensors and simple mechanics in art, attempting to give life-like qualities to otherwise indifferent objects.

Conversation turned towards hacker spaces–what would make the ideal hacker space?  How do you build a vibrant, useful community for DIY projects, tinkering, and learning?  I myself returned to university, itching with anticipation, to once again have the resources, technology, and equipment that I couldn't afford on my own to be readily available with a swipe of that coveted student ID, but I was quickly disappointed.  There's often lots of heavy, expensive equipment dispersed in labs throughout the campus—but it's either limited to students in particular programs or there is no one readily available to teach those interested in how to use it (a certain, dusty stereoscopic screen comes to mind.)

We did have the luck, though, of visiting public artist Andrew Shoben's workshop for <a href="http://www.greyworld.org/">Greyworld</a>, and were delighted to be bestowed a shopping list for the beginner's workshop:  a multimeter, soldering irons and solder wire, basic stamps, arduinos, empty boxes and cases, electronic kits for circuit making, screwdriver set, wire

<img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-344 alignright" title="arduino-workshop-kit" src="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2009/04/arduino-workshop-kit-150x150.jpg" alt="An arduino workshop kit" width="150" height="150" />

cutters, lots of power strips, a basic electronics manual, and a Wii fit (somewhat facetiously added.)  We built on that wish list, pretty ambitiously, with the idea that our ideal studio space would have a collection of tools we already know how to use, plus new items we could tinker with and explore.

Unlike university studios, hacker spaces and similar endeavors suggest a more informal, eclectic (and less expensive) atmosphere. Those in existence now often require a small joining or membership fee, and are stuffed with work tables with soldering irons, shelves stocked with a mix of electronics, bits, bobs, and gutted appliances to recycle, funky admirable projects underway littered about (think Doc Brown's garage in Back To The Future meets a grad student office.)

<img class="size-medium wp-image-342 alignleft" title="docbrown" src="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2009/04/docbrown-300x245.jpg" alt="Mad, er benevolent, Doc Brown tinkering in his garage" width="210" height="172" />

A quick <a href="http://www.google.co.uk/search?q=hacker+spaces&amp;ie=utf-8&amp;oe=utf-8&amp;aq=t&amp;rls=org.mozilla:en-US:official&amp;client=firefox-a">google search</a> produced a long list of current spaces available, as well as wikis set up for the express purpose of founding future spaces and providing links to local known hacker spaces and meet ups.  The London-based hacker spaces have an adorable proclivity for tea and biscuits.

There also appears to be a wide range in what folks expect of a hacker space in terms of who is there, and who can join.  At one of our <a href="http://www.mztek.org/pub-meet/">Unplugged</a> sessions, one friend mentioned that in their ideal hacker space, ex's would be forbidden—ex-boyfriends, ex-girlfriends, ex-colleagues, ex-spouses, etc.  Another lamented the less-tech-y visitors distract the pros with constant questions and pleas for help on their own projects.

Earlier in April, Ruth Catlow of net art collective <a href="http://furtherfield.org">Furtherfield.org</a> and <a href="http://www.http.uk.net/">HTTP gallery</a> talked about her earlier days experimenting in net art at <a href="http://bak.spc.org/]">Backspace</a> in London.  Based in a building set against the Thames, Backspace was started in the '90s by a group of new media artists interested in emerging technologies and providing a central space where fellow artists, tinkerers, and makers could drop by and work on projects or learn (collaboratively or independently.)  Ruth chatted a bit about her days there, learning HTML, and borrowing broadband from surrounding companies.

Their web site—endearingly frozen in the '90s with animated gifs running amok and pixellated graphics—doesn't come with many pictures that I could find, but shows the space is a stone's throw from the Thames and had a kitchen available to visitors.

We've been discussing quite a bit about what sort of workspace we would want for MzTEK, and <a href="http://www.spacestudios.org.uk/">[ Space ]</a> will provide us with their aptly spacious front space for workshops—equipped with lovely new Macs loaded with software and a projector.   One of our goals is to provide participants on the <a href="http://www.mztek.org/workshops/">U-TEK course</a> with that coveted hacker space—a room with just enough equipment for both tinkering and programming, that allows artists to come and go as they need, build on and house their projects safely and lean on the community of artists and makers about.

Here's a couple of hacker and maker spaces I can think of off the top of my head, plus some useful links:

<a href="http://dek.spc.org/">Deckspace</a>, London
<a href="http://bak.spc.org">Backspace</a>, London
<a href="http://www.nycresistor.com/">NYC Resistor</a> in Brooklyn, New York
<a href="http://missbaltazar.humlab.umu.se/">Miss Baltazar</a> in Umea, Sweden
<a href="https://www.noisebridge.net/wiki/Noisebridge">Noisebridge</a> in San Fran, California

<a href="http://www.spc.org">www.spc.org</a>
<a href="http://Hackerspaces.org">Hackerspaces.org</a>
<a href="http://wiki.hackspace.org.uk/">http://wiki.hackspace.org.uk/</a>
<a href="http://blog.wired.com/gadgets/2009/03/hackerspaces.html">http://blog.wired.com/gadgets/2009/03/hackerspaces.html</a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Next MzTEK Unplugged: Julie Freeman</title>
		<link>http://www.mztek.org/2009/04/next-mztek-unplugged-julie-freeman/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 25 Apr 2009 17:42:56 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Sally</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.mztek.org/?p=335</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[What are you up to, this Wednesday night?  Why not come out to Leon Bankside (directly south &amp; facing the Tate Modern) to join us around the table for another Unplugged sesh?

This week, Julie Freeman will chat about the politics of Open Source software and code, and will introduce some of the useful programs, packages and tools available for artists, and tools she uses in her work.

Julie Freeman’s work explores transforming complex processes into sound compositions, objects and visualizations. Her work spans visual, audio and digital art forms and explores the relationship between science, nature and how humans interact with it.

For the past 12 years, Julie's work has focused on using electronic technologies to “translate nature” – whether through the sound of torrential rain falling on a giant rhubarb leaf, a pair of mobile concrete speakers lurking in galleries haranguing passers by or by providing an interactive platform from which to view the flap, twitch and prick of dogs’ ears. Her pioneering artwork The Lake used hydrophones, custom software and advanced technology to track electronically tagged fish and translate their movement into an audio-visual experience.

Julie holds an MA in Digital Art from the Lansdown Centre for Electronic Arts, Middlesex University, and is a NESTA fellow and Wellcome Trust arts awardee. Her work has been exhibited across the UK, including at the Institute of Contemporary Arts and the Science Museum, and internationally in Brazil, Croatia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Russia, and the USA.

www.translatingnature.org

<strong>Where:</strong> Leon Bankside (directly behind the Tate Modern) Closest tubes: Southwark, London Bridge
<strong>When: </strong> Wednesday, April 29, 7pm — 9pm

MzTEK Unplugged is a fortnightly talk series open to everyone &amp; free.  We gather around a table for a drink and interesting conversation, inviting renowned artists and technologists to discuss a range of topics in the arts, new media, and technology.

You don't have to be techy to get involved —  a curiosity for the arts and computing helps!

[ Here's a <a href="http://www.mztek.org/open-sourcery-…re-for-artistsopen-sourcery-software-for-artists/" target="_self">comprehensive list</a> Julie created for MzTEK of Open Source software for artists.]]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Next P2P workshop - Photoshop </title>
		<link>http://www.mztek.org/2009/05/next-p2p-workshop-photoshop/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 05 May 2009 08:29:16 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Sophie</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.mztek.org/?p=349</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Calling women MzTEKers and techies!

Photoshop Workshop

The next Peer2 Peer workshop is going to be a  Photoshop workshop lead by Laura.

date for your diary... 14th MAY from 7pm - 9pm

Laura is keen to know what you want to know (photoshop for web? photoshop for photographers?), and what level you would like the workshop to be aimed at (beginners intro or advanced skills and techniques?). Please RSVP with thoughts and requirements to info@mztek.org or leave a comment on this post.

Although this will be mainly a photoshop workshop (a useful tool as it is the media industry standard), Laura will also take some time to introduce in brief some of the Open Source tools available for image processing, such as
<a href="http://seashore.sourceforge.net/index.php">Seashore,</a>
<a href="http://gimp.lisanet.de/Website/Overview.html">Gimp</a>
<a href="http://www.macupdate.com/info.php/id/18954/inkscape">Inkscape </a>(for vectors)
If your are interested we will arrange another geek-out with pizza session to explore these tools in more depth.

the workshop will take place at SPACE media in Hackney
129 - 131 Mare St
Hackney
E8 3RH

14th May  7pm - 9pm]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>MzTEK Unplugged: Jim Prevett **WED JUNE 24th, 7-9pm**</title>
		<link>http://www.mztek.org/2009/06/mztek-unplugged-jim-prevett/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 18 Jun 2009 12:07:53 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Sophie</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.mztek.org/?p=358</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Come and join us for the last MzTEK Unplugged b4 schools out 4 summer.

This Wednesday 24th June from 7-9pm
Location:
Leon restaurant, 12 Ludgate Circus, London EC4M 7LQ

<a href="http://maps.google.com/maps/ms?hl=en&amp;geocode=&amp;ie=UTF8&amp;om=1&amp;msa=0&amp;msid=106000309244585811318.0004627a5e16ecbff9a01&amp;ll=51.514218,-0.103705&amp;spn=0.004707,0.012059&amp;z=17" target="_blank">Map</a>

Jim Prevett will present

Power Up art- A short history of technology and art.
Technology has difficult relationship with art. it has a history of challenging the status quo and potentially democratising art. Gradually challenging technologies tend to become integrated into the art gallery structure. This will briefly show some of the pioneering works leading through from ink to telecommunications .

Jim Prevett studied Fine Art (Sculpture) at Sheffield Hallam University in 1999. He works with prevett &amp; mcArthur who have exhibited across the UK and internationally including 'Echo City' at the British Pavilion for Venice Biennale of Architecture 2006, The Perfect Real at King Street Arts Centre and ‘His life is full of miracles…' videotech at Site Gallery Sheffield. Jim ran the arts programme for Access Space in Sheffield for 2 years establishing a residency programme and producing LOSS Livecode, a festival of 'livecoding' audio. Access Space is the UK’s first recycled technology medialab, using open source software to invigorate old computers and creativity using computers. Jim has worked with Encounters community based arts organisation in Sheffield and as part of New Dust.

Jim currently works as the Emergent Technologies Producer at SPACE media in Hackney, where he runs programmes such as the PermaCultures series of residencies and workshops and FutureTV youth media development. He is an Associate Lecturer on the undergraduate Fine Art (media) course at at Sheffield Hallam University. Jim lives and works in London and Sheffield.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>MzTEK Unplugged: Sarah Angliss</title>
		<link>http://www.mztek.org/2009/05/mztek-unplugged-sarah-angliss/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 21 May 2009 16:39:15 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Sophie</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.mztek.org/?p=375</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[7pm to 9pmish - 27th May 2009

<img src="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2009/01/spacedogfiling3.jpg" alt="spacedogfiling3" title="spacedogfiling3" width="120" height="141" class="alignleft size-full wp-image-392" />
<strong>Better living through ALife</strong>
<br />
Sound artist, engineer and semi-competent programmer Sarah Angliss (Spacedog UK) shares a handful of cunningly simple tricks, inspired by animals, that can be used to make your exhibits, programs and anything else you can dream of more sublime. Use 'bee vision' to track small moving objects with very little computing power. Borrow some ideas from Darwian evolution to solve problems at great speed. Give people the impression you've made a really intelligent robot, when there's very little 'under the hood'. Sarah is coming fresh from her music and automata show Electroplasm at the Brighton festival fringe, where she performed to rave reviews.
<br />

<h3>Location: </h3> Leon restaurant, Bankside,  7 Canvey Street (Behind the Tate Modern) London SE1 9AN <a href="http://maps.google.com/maps/ms?hl=en&geocode=&ie=UTF8&om=1&msa=0&msid=106000309244585811318.0004627a5e16ecbff9a01&ll=51.506205,-0.098598&spn=0.004902,0.012059&z=17">map</a> <br /> <br />]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Next Unplugged: Ilze Black **Wed 3rd June 7-9pm **</title>
		<link>http://www.mztek.org/2009/05/next-unplugged-ilze-black-wed-3rd-june-7-9pm/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 29 May 2009 11:24:20 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Sophie</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.mztek.org/?p=384</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Come and chill out with a cool beer and have a chat with new media artist and producer Ilze Black.

Ilze will talk about her work as media artist and producer. She has curated numerous media productions, art events and happenings in and around London during last 10 years. In 1990s post-Soviet Latvia, Ilze helped to set up the
seminal art initiative art bureau OPEN, and staged seminal events like Open, Biosport and the Untitled: subvertising session in the streets of Riga. In 2003 Ilze Co-founded new media society Take2030. Her projects focus on network populism, free wireless, open communities and transnational society.


Ilze is currently media arts curator at <a href="http://www.watermans.org.uk">Watermans art centre</a> London and is an associate of <a href="http://hivenetworks.net/tiki-view_articles.php">HiveNetworks</a>, <a href="http://www.claswargames.net">Class Wargames</a> and <a href="http://www.nodel.org/">Node.London</a>.

<h2>Location:</h2>
Leon restaurant, Bankside, 7 Canvey Street (Behind the Tate Modern) London
SE1 9AN
<a href="http://maps.google.com/maps/ms?hl=en&geocode=&ie=UTF8&om=1&msa=0&msid=106000309244585811318.0004627a5e16ecbff9a01&ll=51.506205,-0.098598&spn=0.004902,0.012059&z=17">MAP</a>
]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Next Peer to Peer: Arduinorama</title>
		<link>http://www.mztek.org/2009/06/next-peer-to-peer-arduinorama/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 03 Jun 2009 11:22:10 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Sally</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.mztek.org/?p=405</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[NB:  If you would like to attend, please RSVP by <a href="mailto:info@mztek.org">email</a>.

Kit: If you have your own Arduino starter kit, or Arduino and sensors, bring them so you can follow along with your own tools.  You can buy them online in advance if you don't have them.

Or, if you're simply interested in the tech, you're welcome to look on!

We recommend buying one in advance if you want to be able to take home what you've made and use it in your own projects, and in our upcoming workshops.

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-409" title="arduinorama" src="http://www.mztek.org/wp-content/uploads/2009/06/arduinorama.jpg" alt="arduinorama" width="500" height="500" />]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Open Sourcery: Software for Artists</title>
		<link>http://www.mztek.org/2009/06/open-sourcery-software-for-artists/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 01 Jun 2009 20:09:51 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Sally</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.mztek.org/?p=415</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The follow list of links was provided to us courtesy of new media artist <a href="http://www.translatingnature.org" target="_blank">Julie Freeman</a> after her <a href="http://www.mztek.org/next-mztek-unplugged-julie-freeman/" target="_blank">Unplugged talk</a>, to encourage MzTEK and her crew to seek out and use open source software wherever possible.  Thanks Julie!!!

Learn more about <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_source" target="_blank">Open Source</a> and <a href="http://www.opensource.org/" target="_blank">why you should use it</a>, where you can.

<strong>Sound editing, recording, mixing, etc</strong>
<a href="http://audacity.sourceforge.net/" target="_blank">Audacity</a>
<a href="http://www.ardour.org/" target="_blank">Ardour</a>

<strong>Word processing/Spreadsheet/Basic Drawing/Presentation</strong>
<a href="http://www.openoffice.org" target="_blank">OpenOffice</a>
<a href="http://www.neooffice.org" target="_blank">NeoOffice</a> (OpenOffice port for OSX)

<strong>Desk top publishing/document layout for print</strong>
<a href="http://www.scribus.net" target="_blank">Scribus</a>

<strong>Music player/audio manager</strong>
<a href="http://getsongbird.com" target="_blank">Songbird</a>
<strong>
Media player </strong>(plus encoder for formatting video and audio for streaming etc)
<a href="http://www.videolan.org/vlc/" target="_blank">VLC</a>

<strong>Visual programming language</strong> (similar to Max/MSP)
<a href="http://puredata.info/" target="_blank">PD</a>

<strong>Project management</strong>
<a href="http://openproj.org/" target="_blank">OpenProj</a>
<a href="http://www.clockingit.com/" target="_blank">ClockingIT</a>

<strong>Photo and bitmap graphic manipulator</strong><a href="http://www.gimp.org/" target="_blank">
GIMP</a>

<strong>Vector graphic drawing package for illustrations etc</strong>
<a href="http://www.inkscape.org/" target="_blank">Inkscape</a>

<strong>3D graphic package</strong>
<a href="http://www.blender.org/" target="_blank">Blender</a>

<strong>Simplified Java based programming language for artists</strong>
<a href="http://processing.org/" target="_blank">Processing</a>

An OS Flash equivalent doesn't exist yet but people are beavering away at it...
<a href="http://osflash.org/open_source_flash_projects" target="_blank">http://osflash.org/open_source_flash_projects</a>

I also haven't listed an OS equivalent of Final Cut Pro or Premier, but this sit has links - would be interested in any feedback if anyone has used any of these.
<a href="http://www.osalt.com/final-cut-pro" target="_blank">http://www.osalt.com/final-cut-pro</a>

Mentioned by others:

<strong>Flash player</strong> (I've not checked this out)<a href="http://www.gnu.org/software/gnash/" target="_blank">
Gnash</a>

CanvasPaint - an online version of MS Paint

And of course - <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_open_source_software_packages" target="_blank">there are LOADS mor</a>e...

<strong>Other useful links:</strong>

<a href="http://www.messageinabox.tacticaltech.org/" target="_blank">http://www.messageinabox.tacticaltech.org/</a>
<a href="http://www.digitalartistshandbook.org/" target="_blank">http://www.digitalartistshandbook.org/</a>
<a href="http://socialsourcecommons.org/" target="_blank">http://socialsourcecommons.org/</a>

Questions?  Comments?  Please comment if you have experience with the above software you would like to share, or futher suggestions.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>open-sourcery-software-for-artists</wp:post_name>
